Die Environmental Justice Foundation (EJF) hat es sich zur Aufgabe gemacht, unsere gemeinsame Erde und das grundlegende Menschenrecht auf eine sichere Umwelt zu verteidigen.

Investigative Untersuchungen und Filme sind unsere wichtigsten Werkzeuge, um weltweit Missstände aufzudecken. Gleichzeitig unterstützen wir Aktivist:innen, indigene Gruppen, betroffene Gemeinschaften und unabhängige Journalist:innen, die an vorderster Front für Umweltgerechtigkeit kämpfen.

Mit unserer Arbeit tragen wir zur transparenten politischen Entscheidungsfindung bei - für grundlegende, langfristige Reformen zum Schutz der natürlichen Umwelt und der Menschenrechte und eine friedliche, gerechte und nachhaltige Zukunft.

May 2024
The EU’s wider Margins of Tolerance for unsorted catch: An opportunity to lead by example and prevent hidden overfishing globally
 © Jürgen Freund - WWF

 In late 2023, the EU completed its revision of the EU Fisheries Control Regulation (FCR), which included adjustments to the rules on the so-called ‘margin of tolerance’ (MoT): the maximum difference allowed between the catch recorded in the electronic logbook at sea, and the final figures recorded at landing. Notably, by way of derogation, the EU’s co-legislators (the Council of the EU and the European Parliament) allowed a wider MoT for certain fleets landing unsorted catch - such as purse seiners targeting tropical tuna - but only under specific conditions. These conditions, which are aimed at ensuring that these fleets’ catch reporting is accurate, will set additional rules for landing and weighing operations, and would need to be met in EU approved ‘listed ports’. Both the conditions and the list of ports will be established through implementing acts by the European Commission, subject to the approval by a qualified majority of Member States by 10 July 2024.
This guidance note argues that requiring stricter control measures and uniform conditions for inspecting landings and weighing of unsorted catch in selected ports are necessary to ensure consistency with EU law, lower the risk of misreporting, and avoid damage to the EU’s international standing. It also posits that applying this derogation in ‘EU listed ports’ in a way that ensures that any errors can be and are corrected following landing of unsorted catch, is also an opportunity for the EU to better control hidden overfishing and to lead by example globally. Finally, this briefing offers recommendations on the safeguards, exclusion of ports of convenience and transparency measures needed to achieve the level of control that is adequate and necessary for this wider margin of tolerance to apply in ports, including in third country ports where EU-flagged (purse seine) vessels are observed to make extended calls.
 1

 Recommendations: the conditions on the MoT
derogation should:
1. Require additional safeguards that ensure adequate control with:
● A longer prior notification period, of at least 72 hours, for EU vessels landing an unsorted catch. European Commission’s approval of any shorter notification periods for vessels landing unsorted catch and only after the responsible flag Member State(s) can guarantee it can conduct physical inspection on time.
● Higher mandatory target rates of enhanced inspections in listed ports, of at least 17%, with a risk-based approach that prioritises inspection of ‘serial offenders’ of the MoT derogation.
● The use of accredited independent third parties, where deemed necessary, whose independence should be confirmed by the Member State concerned.
2. Ensure exclusion of any potential ‘ports of convenience’, including those located in third countries that are:
● Failing to comply with the PSMA and (as relevant) RFMO rules on inspections of landing or weighing based on reasonable doubt;
● ‘Yellow’ or ‘red’ carded countries under the IUU carding scheme.
● Refusing EU or Member State inspectors to conduct the required level of inspection on EU
vessels.
● Refusing officials from the EU to verify compliance with relevant SFPA provisions (such as on
joint inspections).
3. Ensure the transparency of enforcement by:
● Requiring Member States to aggregate information and report annually on enforcement of the MoT derogation, including the number of inspections on EU vessels conducted jointly with a third country, within one year from the entry into force of the implementing act for MoT derogation.
● Requiring Member States to notify the European Commission immediately if there is a risk of a listed port no longer complying with the conditions set out in the implementing act on the MoT derogation
● Requiring the European Commission to make publicly available a compilation of information from the reports on Member States’ efforts to control compliance with the MoT derogation.
 2

 Why stricter control measures and uniform
conditions are necessary
The revision of the EU fisheries control system,1 which entered into force in January 2024, did not change the general rule on how much room EU vessels have to misreport their catches: namely, a margin of tolerance (MoT) of 10 % per species.2 However, the co-legislators considered that complying with this general rule involved “challenges of accurately estimating on board catches”3 for certain fisheries that land unsorted catch. Article 14(4) has therefore been introduced into the revised Fisheries Control Regulation4 (FCR), granting a larger MoT to small pelagic fisheries, industrial fisheries and tropical tuna purse seine fisheries when unsorted catch is being landed.5 The provision further specifies that this wider MoT can only apply if unsorted catch is being landed by these EU vessels in ports that meet conditions concerning landing and weighing that can “ensure accurate catch reporting”6. Based on the submission of Member States, the Commission is to approve ports that meet the conditions. The Commission can subsequently amend this list and “may revoke its approval of a listed port in the event that the conditions are no longer met”7. Both the conditions and the first list of ports should be adopted by 10 July 2024 through implementing acts.8
This guidance note argues that the framework for permitting certain EU vessels the use of the wider MoT must be based on uniform conditions which are exceptionally applied and based on stricter conditions for landing and weighing. This is necessary to (1) ensure consistency with EU law, (2) prevent misreporting, and (3) and avoid damage to the EU’s international standing.
Reason 1: Ensure consistency with EU law
There would not be consistency with EU law if the implementing act specifying the conditions for applying a derogation allowing a wider MoT would not (A) require stricter control measures and (B) uniform conditions.
(A) Stricter control measures
Article 14(4)(a) of the revised FCR expressly stipulates that the new, wider MoT that may be applied “by way of derogation”9 (see appendix below) is conditional. It applies: "in the case of landings in listed ports and” is to be “subject to additional conditions concerning the landing and the weighing of catches in order to ensure accurate catch reporting” (emphasis added). In addition to the revised FCR’s provisions clearly stipulating that this is a derogation that is only applied if certain conditions are met, it is

 worth recalling three relevant areas of case law of the CJEU that reaffirm the principle that conditional derogations need to be interpreted strictly and applied exceptionally.
Firstly (1), in European Commission v Malta (C-557/15) — a case lost by Malta for failing to demonstrate conditions were in place to exceptionally allow a derogation for trapping of protected bird species in Natura 2000 areas — the Court recalled that “exceptional arrangements” like conditionally applicable derogations, need to be “interpreted strictly”.10 It added that Member State authorities must prove “conditions exist for each derogation” (for it to lawfully apply in their jurisdiction) and:
“ensure that all action affecting the protected species is authorised only on the basis of decisions containing a clear and sufficient statement of reasons which refers to the /.../ conditions and requirements laid down.”11(emphasis added).
Secondly (2), it is settled EU case law that when an undefined term appears in a derogation, it must be interpreted strictly12. The term “accurate catch reporting” of Article 14(4) is not explicitly defined in the revised FCR13. However, in PF, MF v Ireland (C-564/20), a ruling that covered Article 14 of the Regulation (EC) No 1224/2009 and the Member States obligations to ensure “the accuracy of the catch figures”, the CJEU ruled that:
“Member States can properly monitor the uptake of quotas and contribute to the achievement of the objectives of the CFP /.../ only if they can ensure that they have accurate and comprehensive information and data on fishing opportunities”.14 (emphasis added)
Thirdly (3), in Parliament v Commission (C-65/13), a case in which the European Parliament tried (and failed) to argue that the Commission had gone beyond implementing powers that bestowed on it in a legislative act, the CJEU ruled that the Commission is authorised, with reference to the “essential general aims of the legislative act in question” to produce “all measures necessary... for the implementation of the basic legislation” but not those “contrary to it”.15 (emphasis added)
On the first (1) point: It is clear that Article 14(4) of the revised FCR is a derogation that should apply conditionally. Ensuing, as per Commission v Malta, the Commission should strictly interpret its implementing powers in laying down the conditions for the expanded MoT derogation. Since the wording of this article refers to “additional conditions”, it is clear that the conditions to be applied must go beyond the rules for control on landing and weighing already set out (in the FCR, or elsewhere), including those stipulated in Article 60 of the Revised FCR. This is also clear from the considerations of the co-legislators16, as laid out in the recitals. These note that the conditions should “ensure adequate control over such operation[s]”17 (emphasis added). Without stricter conditions for landing and weighing the accuracy of catch reporting cannot be ensured, as also the

 experience from the Baltic Sea demonstrated [see Box 2]. As vessels will have significantly more incentive to misreport at landing under the MoT derogation applicable for landings of unsorted catch [see APPENDIX], the risk of not ensuring accurate catch reporting increases if the conditions do not go beyond the standard level control on weighing and landing.
On the second (2) and third (3) points: It would be inconsistent with the logic of PF, MF v Ireland (C-564/20) and Parliament v Commission (C-65/13), to allow more room for misreporting via a more flexible MoT. It is clear from C-564/20 in particular that the need to ensure the accuracy of catch reporting is tied to an “essential general aim” (in the sense of C-65/13) of the legislation in question - namely, “monitoring of quota uptake” and “contributing to achieving CFP objective” of ensuring marine biological resources are exploited sustainably.18,19 Putting in place stricter conditions for the application of this MoT derogation to ensure the accuracy of catch reporting at landing is therefore a must. This view is reinforced by the considerations of the co-legislators, which recalled that:
In order to achieve the objectives of the common fisheries policy, the reliability and comprehensive collection of data on catches is of the utmost importance. For that purpose, it is necessary to strengthen the procedures concerning the weighing of fishery products upon landing, without creating disproportionate burdens on operators”20 (emphasis added).
In short, EU case law demonstrates that any derogation needs to be applied exceptionally and interpreted strictly, and that the broader MoT requires additional rules that can ensure the accuracy of catch reporting with adequate control in port. Coupled with the considerations and the provisions of the Regulation No 2023/2842, it can be argued that to require a level of control in listed ports considered to be adequate, such control of EU vessels’ landing and weighing operations in port must be stricter than foreseen by standard rules. Not to do so would be contrary to the EU case law and demands of the co-legislators, as anything but stricter control will not be able to guarantee the accuracy of catch reporting, and by extension, the monitoring of quota uptake.
(B) Uniform conditions
Based on EU primary (EU treaties, case law) and secondary law (the FCR), the conditions under a wider MoT for inspection of unsorted catch at landing must be, at minimum, uniform and applicable in EU and non-EU ports alike.
The Treaty on the Functioning of the EU provides that the Commission lays down “uniform conditions” in an implementing act “where [these] are needed”21. The Court of Justice of the EU (CJEU) has confirmed that such acts must be capable of ensuring that the legislative act in question “is implemented under uniform conditions in all Member States”22. This language is echoed by the co-legislators in the revised FCR. They indicated that conditions for allowing the derogation foreseen in Article 14(4) should be both capable of ensuring the “adequate control” and be “uniform”23. It does

To the contrary, the revised FCR specifies that the same listing conditions could apply for the EU and non-EU ports, highlighting “the necessary control by and cooperation with the relevant competent authorities of the third country concerned” should be provided for24. This is consistent with the general principles of fisheries control set out in Article 5 of the Fisheries Control Regulation25, which specify that Member States should conduct control on fishing vessels in a non-discriminatory way and based on risk management.26 Applying a different or even lower standard to an EU vessel landing in an EU port compared to another in a non-EU port, would not just be discriminatory, but also ineffective risk management, given that it could increase the risk of misreporting for EU vessels landing in certain third country ports [see box 3].
It would therefore be inconsistent with principles of uniform and non-discriminatory application of EU law, as well as risk management, to not require the conditions of the MoT implementing act to apply uniformly to ports in and outside the EU.
Reason 2: Preventing increased misreporting
The aforementioned legal recognition of the importance of accurate catch reporting is based on a fundamental principle in fisheries management: to know what is left in the ocean, you need to know what was taken out of it.27,28 In other words, it is essential for the recovery of overfished fish populations - like yellowfin or bigeye tuna in the Indian Ocean29 - that the accuracy of catch reporting by the EU fleet is effectively controlled, including at landing. Unfortunately, catch misreporting “remains a major issue in EU fisheries”, as recognised by the European Court of Auditors.30
In general, the quality of port control at landing affects the likelihood of operators to misreport their catch. In the EU, checks on landings by Member States have been found by the European Commission to be deficient across several Member States. An unpublished European Commission audit report from 2022 found that in “most Member States, the vast majority of landings are not inspected/controlled.”31 Lack of inspection may encourage vessel operators to land in ports where inspections and controls at landing and at weighing are weak, as they will likely be able to avoid inspection and have the opportunity to “illegally ‘stretch’” fishing opportunities by underreporting

However, not all ports are equal. The risk of misreporting caused by weak port control is even higher and compounded when the landing takes place (1) in a port with an increased MoT, (2) in hub ports and (3) and in ports where physical inspection is impossible due to lack of jurisdiction.
(1) Incentives to misreport in a port with an increased MoT
Firstly, when the rate of inspection remains low, the incentive to illegally “tamper” with the standard margin of tolerance of 10% per species increases:
“For example, it's perfectly possible for a fishing vessel to catch 1,100 tonnes of fish. But in their estimate, they say "We caught 1,000 tonnes of fish." Then they arrive in port and in the very unlikely case that there is a control, the difference is within 10%, so that's OK. The problem here is that in 99% of cases, there is no control. It's basically fishermen weighing their own fish. They then can claim in their landing declaration: 'oh we caught 9,000 tonnes of fish' - and that's also within 10% of the estimation that was made on board. But this is a 20% difference."33
This incentive to misreport quota species rises when the margin of tolerance itself is increased. This has demonstrably been the case in the Baltic Sea. Under Regulation No 2016/1139, a derogation applied to any vessel landing sprat or herring unsorted, allowed reporting quota species like sprat to be reported as non-quota species (like sandeel).3435 Under such conditions, the rate of misreporting can reach stratospheric levels (Box 1).
    Box 1: Misreporting with an increased MoT and weak port control: Baltic port of Simrishamn Simrishamn is a Swedish port where industrial vessels have been observed landing unsorted species, which
are then transported for first sale to other ports in the EU (such as those in Denmark).36 It is a port where the Baltic MoT has been applied.
According to a report from a European Commission mission to Sweden in 2022 to verify compliance with the Basic FCR, the “vast majority of landings” in Simrishamn were not inspected. Unsorted landings were “at best” weighed in bulk on weighbridges - without samples being taken to check how much of each species was taken (in non-compliance with provisions on weighing in Regulation (EC) No 1224/2009). As a result of improper weighing and lack of verification, the figures on catch reported for each species following landing (in the landing and take-over declarations, sales notes, and transport documents) were described as “arbitrary” or “based on logbook estimates”37.

Relaxing the margin of tolerance without requiring strengthened port control further “incentivises” operators to ‘stretch’ their fishing opportunities by underreporting quota species.41
(2) Incentive to misreport in hub ports (with weak port control)
Analysis shows that ports serving as hubs for fishing vessels, because they have infrastructure and facilities to land, process and/or export fish at scale - as well as weak port inspections - are more likely to be particularly attractive for unscrupulous operators wishing to ‘conceal’ their actual catch.42 A 2015 study found that it is not the “the level of economic development” that plays a determining role in where such operators decide to land their catch43; rather, it is hub ports (with their better port infrastructure and higher vessel traffic) that have ‘high concealability’ and weak ‘governance’, i.e., lacking port control and inspections at landing, that seem to significantly attract such vessel operators.44 Indeed, the increased risk (and extent) of catch misreporting resulting from weak control has been observed in hub ports in the EU as well (box 1).
    Box 2: Underreporting of quota species under failing control? The case of the ‘hub’ port Ijmuiden
The port of Ijmuiden, the Netherlands, has seen some of the largest industrial fishing vessels land very large volumes of catch45. This can largely be attributed to Ijmuiden’s port strategic location and infrastructure (cold storage, container facilities, etc.), which has made it a hub for fish landings by EU-flagged (pelagic freezer) vessels, such as those owned by Dutch companies, and (non-EU flagged) ones. This infrastructure also has made it logistically key for seafood (re)exports in the EU and beyond - such as West African markets.46
However, the landings of (large pelagic) fishing vessels in Ijmuiden may also be linked to the quality of control and capacity for inspection at landing47. Carpenter (2023), ‘Review of "Socio-economic study of the impact of the margin of tolerance on the French tropical tuna fishery". http://www.transparentfisheries.org/wp-content/uploads/2023/01/Review-of-Socio-economic-study-of-the-impact-of-the-margin-of-tolerance-on-the-French-tropic al-tuna-fishery.pdf (Last accessed 15 April 2024).
105 Ibid, p.3.
     16

 A third approach, should in addition foresee the use of “accredited independent third parties” (ACTP), wherever possible, to verify weighing records to guarantee the accuracy of catch reporting at landing. However, it is critical that their independence (from both the buyer of the landed catch, and its seller) is ensured by the Member State whose vessels will be inspected by the ACTP, and that it is clear that the burden is on the Member State to prove that this third party remains independent and capable of guaranteeing the accuracy of catch reporting.
In short, it is recommended to establish safeguards for EU vessels’ landing and weighing operations that can ensure adequate control and guarantee the accuracy of catch reporting, namely by requiring:
(a) Alongerpriornotificationperiod,ofatleast72h,forEUvesselslandingunsortedcatch. European Commission’s approval of any shorter notification periods for vessels landing unsorted catch and only after the responsible flag Member State(s) can guarantee it can conduct physical inspection on time.
(b) Highermandatorytargetratesofenhancedinspectionsinlistedports,ofatleast17%,witha risk-based approach that prioritises inspection of ‘serial offenders’ of the MoT derogation;
(c) The use of accredited independent third parties, where deemed necessary, whose independence should be confirmed by the Member State concerned.
(2) Exclude any potential ‘ports of convenience’, including those located in third countries
To ensure uniform application of the MoT derogation rules across the EU and in third country ports, cooperation with authorities in third countries is critical. If this cannot be ensured, those third country ports should be excluded from the list of ports where the wider MoT derogation could apply.
This is also clear from the considerations of the co-legislators (as noted above): third country ports cannot be listed where “cooperation” with the “relevant competent authorities” is not in place, and the “necessary control” on the application of the derogation cannot be guaranteed. Ports that do not fulfil these conditions may be called ports of convenience, i.e.: “/w/here a port State is unwilling or unable to exercise measures to combat IUU fishing activities, such as inspections to detect IUU-caught fish, and prohibitions on landing of illegal catches.”106107 In these cases, incentives for deliberate loosening of control have been said to exist “often in areas that are already struggling economically”, as (especially) larger fishing companies and vessels are believed to bring “money and jobs”. This can lead to a vicious cycle where (Member) States “compete”108 with each other to have lower controls. Conversely, an upwards cycle can be instilled if the EU encourages international cooperation and excludes any port of convenience.109
106 Environmental Justice Foundation (2009) Dirty Fish – How EU Hygiene Standards facilitates illegal fishing in West Africa, p.3. https://ejfoundation.org/resources/downloads/report-dirty-fish.pdf (last checked 15 April 2024).
107 It is worth noting that advisory councils (MAC and LDAC) have argued for the need of the Commission to encourage effective implementation of the PSMA. JOINT MAC-LDAC ADVICE (2021). Fostering the European Union’s leadership in reducing the detrimental impact of flags of convenience in the fishing sector, p.7. https://marketac.eu/wp-content/uploads/2021/10/MAC-LDAC-Joint-Advice-Flags-of-Convenience-08.10.2021-EN.pdf (last checked 15 April 2024).
108 Conversely, incentives to tighten control may not be there “If controls are too strict, companies may decide to land their catch elsewhere” (translated from Dutch). Bram Logger and Parcival Weijnen (2021), ‘Twee Inspecteurs voor de Totale Zee’ Groene Amsterdammer’ Groene Amsterdammer. https://www.groene.nl/artikel/twee-inspecteurs-voor-de-totale-zee (last checked 11 April 2024). The Dutch control authority has denied these allegations. Idem.
109 E.g. tropical tuna purse seiners will have financial incentives to land in EU-approved ports, and to avoid landing in ‘ports of convenience’. In turn, port authorities will have incentives to ensure they can meet the standards.
      17

 How to achieve this? The revised FCR already provides guidance. Firstly, it emphasises the need to amend the Fisheries Control Regulation ((EC) No 1224/2009) in a way that is “consistent with the Union’s international obligations, including those under the 2009 /... / Agreement on Port State Measures to Prevent, Deter and Eliminate Illegal, Unreported and Unregulated Fishing.”110 Accordingly, where the European Commission finds that a third country does not meet the standards for weighing and inspection of the PSMA111 (and/or as relevant RFMO112) it should exclude its ports from the consideration of listing. Where the European Commission has reasonable doubt regarding the level of compliance, the port should also not be listed.
Secondly, the revised FCR indicates that: “/t/o strengthen the measures against non-cooperating third countries in fighting IUU fishing... the access to port services and the conduct of landing or transhipment operations in Union ports by fishing vessels flying the flag of such third countries should be prohibited.”113 For the purpose of consistency with EU policy on IUU fishing, if a third country has “presumed deficiencies in the control system”114 and has been (pre)identified as a (possible) non-cooperating third country (i.e., ‘yellow’ or ‘red’ card),115,116 it should be excluded from being listed as a port where an MOT derogation could apply.
Thirdly, where it is (legally) impossible for EU Member
State officials to verify controls and inspections on
landing and weighing operations of their vessels in third country ports (see box 3), Member States cannot adequately verify compliance with the Common Fisheries Policy (CFP) (see box 2) - and thus the port should be excluded fork the possibility of being listed. This should equally be the case if relevant EU officials cannot check compliance with relevant SFPA provisions such as those with provisions on joint inspections on EU vessels (see above map (3)117).
110 Recital 3, Regulation (EU) 2023/2842 .Cf. Food and Agriculture Organisation Agreement on Port State Measures to Prevent, Deter and Eliminate Illegal, Unreported and Unregulated Fishing approved by the Union by Council Decision 2011/443/EU.
111 See. e.g. article 12 of the PSMA states that ” Each party shall inspect the number of vessels in its ports required to reach an annual level of inspections sufficient to achieve the objective of this Agreement”. The objective is to “prevent, deter and eliminate IUU fishing through the implementation of effective port State measures, and thereby to ensure the long-term conservation and sustainable use of living marine resources and marine ecosystems.” See Article 2, PSMA, ratified in 2011/443/EU: Council Decision of 20 June 2011 on the approval, on behalf of the European Union, of the Agreement on Port State Measures to Prevent, Deter and Eliminate Illegal, Unreported and Unregulated Fishing Agreement on Port State Measures to Prevent, Deter and Eliminate Illegal, Unreported and Unregulated Fishing. OJ L 191, 22.7.2011, p. 1–18.
112 Article 4, PSMA (2011/443/EU).
113 Recital 129, Regulation (EU) No 2023/2842.
114 A benchmark criterion for port inspection as per Article 4 (s) of Commission Regulation (EC) No 1010/2009 of 22 October 2009 laying down detailed rules for the implementation of Council Regulation (EC) No 1005/2008 establishing a Community system to prevent, deter and eliminate illegal, unreported and unregulated fishing OJ L 280, 27.10.2009, p. 5–41.
115 “The European Commission is empowered to notify a non-EU country of the risk of being identified as ‘non-cooperating’ in fighting IUU fishing, and can subsequently engage in a formal dialogue with the country and initiate cooperation to resolve identified non-compliance based on an action plan.”. See European Commission (2020) ‘Report from the Commission to the European Parliament and the Council on the application of Council Regulation (EC) No 1005/2008 establishing a community system to prevent, deter and eliminate illegal, unreported and unregulated (IUU) fishing (the EU IUU Regulation), https://eur-lex.europa.eu/legal-content/EN/TXT/?uri=CELEX:52020DC0772, see section 2.1; and Title VI, Council Regulation (EC) No 1005/2008 of 29 September 2008 establishing a Community system to prevent, deter and eliminate illegal, unreported and unregulated fishing, amending Regulations (EEC) No 2847/93, (EC) No 1936/2001 and (EC) No 601/2004 and repealing Regulations (EC) No 1093/94 and (EC) No 1447/1999, OJ L 286, 29.10.2008, p. 1–32.
116 “Member State authorities must take action against countries indicating as non-cooperation, including prohibiting EU-flagged fishing vessels to (via private agreements) “ use the fishing possibilities of such countries” Article 38 (6), Regulation No 1005/2008
117 Created with mapchart.net. Sources: https://oceans-and-fisheries.ec.europa.eu/fisheries/international-agreements/sustainable-fisheries-partnership-agreements-sfpas_en; https://www.iuuwatch.eu/the-iuu-regulation/eu-carding-decisions/.
                 18

 It is therefore recommended to exclude - or if already listed, revoke - any port if the third country where it is located is:
(a) FailingtocomplywiththePSMAand(asrelevant)RFMOrulesoninspectionsoflandingor weighing based on reasonable doubt;
(b) YelloworredcardedcountriesundertheIUUcardingscheme;
(c) Refusing EU or Member State inspectors to conduct the required level of inspection on EU
vessels;
(d) RefusingofficialsfromEUtoverifycompliancewithrelevantSFPAprovisions(suchason
joint inspections).
(3) Ensure the transparency of enforcement
Public information on Member States’ efforts to control the MoT derogation in listed ports is key to assess if the required inspection thresholds (such as the number of inspections at landing) are met.118
The EU co-legislators explicitly affirmed that the success of the CFP depends on a “transparent system of control and enforcement”119 and that “transparency” on “control and inspection” should be ensured.120
Accordingly, Article 93b(2) of the Revised FCR requires Member States to publicly report by 30 June of each year on their fisheries control effort. The information to be reported includes the inspections resources committed, “number and type” of “control and inspections performed”, “detected and confirmed” (serious) infringements, and follow up actions for each type of infringement.121 This rule should enter into force from 10 January 2026. As the MoT derogation could enter into force much earlier, it would be consistent with the transparency provisions of the Regulation No 2023/2842 outlined above to require Member States to also publish this data when their vessels are landing in listed ports at an earlier date, no later than a year from the entry into force of the implementing act laying down the conditions for MoT derogation. In addition, Member States should also note in their report data on joint inspections carried out with a third country on EU vessel landings in listed ports (for example, joint inspections that are conducted based on the provisions of a SFPA122).
Further, an additional safeguard should be introduced, ensuring that the port is delisted where the conditions are no longer met.123 If there is verifiable and independent evidence of a risk of a listed port no longer complying with the conditions set out in the implementing act on the MoT derogation, Member States should be required to notify this to the Commission immediately and publicly report it in their annual report on ensuring compliance with the MoT derogation.
118 Transparency has also been said to be key for EU vessel operators as well, so they can know if they are “equally treated” - which depends in part on having “more public information on the implementation of enforcement measures by Member States”. Europêche (2020). Europêche and environmental NGOs join forces to demand modern, effective and simplified EU fisheries control. https://europeche.chil.me/post/europeche-and-environmental-ngos-join-forces-to-demand-modern-effective-and-simp-320827 (last checked 15 April 2024).
119 Recital 1, Regulation (EU) No 2023/2842.
120 Recital 48, Regulation (EU) No 2023/2842.
121 See Article 93b (2),(a) - (d) Regulation (EU) No 2023/2842 (Amendments to Regulation (EC) No 1224/2009).
122 This is arguably in line with the Opinion of Advocate General Capella, which noted that “"sufficient evidence of strict supervision by the Joint Committee" is needed to “satisfy the European Union’s obligations to respect the sustainable exploitation of the natural resources of the waters" of the third country. Opinion of Advocate General Ćapeta on 21 March 2024, Joined Cases C-778/21 P and C-778/21 P), ECLI:EU:C:2024:258, paragraph 166.
123 As required by Article 14(6), Regulation (EU) No 2023/2842 (Amendments to Regulation (EC) No 1224/2009).
     19

 Finally, since Article 93b (2) of the revised FCR requires the European Commission to make available a compilation of information from the reports on Member States’ control efforts on its website from 31 December 2026124. This should also be required specifically for the MoT ports at an earlier date, no later than 30 June 2025.
In summary, it is thus recommended to increase transparency about the enforcement of the conditional MoT derogation by:
(a) RequiringMemberStatestoshareinareportannuallyup-to-dateandaggregateinformation on the enforcement of the MoT derogation, including the resources allocated and the inspection effort (frequency) per selected port within a year from the entry into force of the implementing act laying down the conditions for MoT derogation. This report should include data on the number and type of inspections and if control is conducted jointly with a third country.
(b) RequireMemberStatestonotifytheCommissionimmediatelyifthereisriskofalistedport no longer complying with the conditions set out in the implementing act on the MoT derogation.
(c) Requiring the European Commission to make publicly available a compilation of information from the reports on Member States efforts to control compliance with the conditional MoT derogation.
 124 Article 93b (3), Regulation (EU) No 2023/2842 (Amendments to Regulation (EC) No 1224/2009).
20

 Conclusion
Recognising the risks of EU vessels underreporting overfished fish populations, such as yellowfin tuna in the Indian Ocean, it is critical that EU Member States uniformly mitigate these risks and ensure the accuracy of catch reporting and science-based management of the EU’s fisheries. The conditions for when a wider margin of tolerance can be used must therefore require stricter control on landings of unsorted catch (e.g., an unsorted landing of juvenile yellowfin and bigeye tuna), so that accordingly, a limited list of (third country) EU approved ports could be listed.
Doing so also presents an opportunity to lead by example: if the EU’s (tropical tuna purse seine) fleet that is landing catch unsorted is strictly controlled, the accuracy of its catch reporting should improve. This will not only benefit the recovery of already overfished tuna populations, but also enable the EU to effectively call on other countries to better and more credibly promote zero tolerance on unreported fishing, such as part of the IUU Fishing Action Alliance. Conversely, failing to do so could affect the food security of third countries and damage the EU’s negotiating position, such as in RFMOs.
Accordingly, EJF and WWF, members of the EU IUU Fishing Coalition, therefore recommend, the conditions on the MoT derogation should:
1. Require additional safeguards that ensure adequate control with:
● A longer prior notification period, of at least 72h, for EU vessels landing unsorted catch. European Commission’s approval of any shorter notification periods for vessels landing unsorted catch and only after the responsible flag Member State(s) can guarantee it can conduct physical inspection on time.
● Higher mandatory target rates of enhanced inspections in listed ports, of at least 17%, with a risk-based approach that prioritises inspection of ‘serial offenders’ of the MoT derogation;
● The use of accredited independent third parties, where deemed necessary, whose independence should be confirmed by the Member State concerned.
2. Ensure exclusion of any potential ‘ports of convenience’, including those located in third countries that are:
● Failing to comply with the PSMA and (as relevant) RFMO rules on inspections of landing or weighing based on reasonable doubt;
● Yellow or red carded countries under the IUU carding scheme;
● Refusing EU or Member State inspectors to conduct the required level of inspection on EU
vessels;
● Refusing officials from EU to verify compliance with relevant SFPA provisions (such as on
joint inspections).
       21

 3. Ensure the transparency of enforcement by:
● Requiring Member States to share in a report annually up-to-date and aggregate information on enforcement of the MoT derogation, including the number of inspections on EU vessels conducted jointly a third country, within one year from the entry into force of the implementing act for MOT derogation;
● Requiring Member States to notify the European Commission immediately if there is risk of a listed port no longer complying with the conditions set out in the implementing act on the MOT derogation;
● Requiring the European Commission to make publicly available a compilation of information from the reports on Member States’ efforts to control compliance with the MOT derogation.
22

  APPENDIX
European Commission, DG MARE D4, Slides relevant to the Margins of Tolerance presented to the Inter-Advisory Council on ‘the revised EU Fisheries Control Regulation’, Brussels 6 January 2024.
  23

May 2024
The EU’s wider Margins of Tolerance for unsorted catch: An opportunity to lead by example and prevent hidden overfishing globally
 © Jürgen Freund - WWF

 In late 2023, the EU completed its revision of the EU Fisheries Control Regulation (FCR), which included adjustments to the rules on the so-called ‘margin of tolerance’ (MoT): the maximum difference allowed between the catch recorded in the electronic logbook at sea, and the final figures recorded at landing. Notably, by way of derogation, the EU’s co-legislators (the Council of the EU and the European Parliament) allowed a wider MoT for certain fleets landing unsorted catch - such as purse seiners targeting tropical tuna - but only under specific conditions. These conditions, which are aimed at ensuring that these fleets’ catch reporting is accurate, will set additional rules for landing and weighing operations, and would need to be met in EU approved ‘listed ports’. Both the conditions and the list of ports will be established through implementing acts by the European Commission, subject to the approval by a qualified majority of Member States by 10 July 2024.
This guidance note argues that requiring stricter control measures and uniform conditions for inspecting landings and weighing of unsorted catch in selected ports are necessary to ensure consistency with EU law, lower the risk of misreporting, and avoid damage to the EU’s international standing. It also posits that applying this derogation in ‘EU listed ports’ in a way that ensures that any errors can be and are corrected following landing of unsorted catch, is also an opportunity for the EU to better control hidden overfishing and to lead by example globally. Finally, this briefing offers recommendations on the safeguards, exclusion of ports of convenience and transparency measures needed to achieve the level of control that is adequate and necessary for this wider margin of tolerance to apply in ports, including in third country ports where EU-flagged (purse seine) vessels are observed to make extended calls.
 1

 Recommendations: the conditions on the MoT
derogation should:
1. Require additional safeguards that ensure adequate control with:
● A longer prior notification period, of at least 72 hours, for EU vessels landing an unsorted catch. European Commission’s approval of any shorter notification periods for vessels landing unsorted catch and only after the responsible flag Member State(s) can guarantee it can conduct physical inspection on time.
● Higher mandatory target rates of enhanced inspections in listed ports, of at least 17%, with a risk-based approach that prioritises inspection of ‘serial offenders’ of the MoT derogation.
● The use of accredited independent third parties, where deemed necessary, whose independence should be confirmed by the Member State concerned.
2. Ensure exclusion of any potential ‘ports of convenience’, including those located in third countries that are:
● Failing to comply with the PSMA and (as relevant) RFMO rules on inspections of landing or weighing based on reasonable doubt;
● ‘Yellow’ or ‘red’ carded countries under the IUU carding scheme.
● Refusing EU or Member State inspectors to conduct the required level of inspection on EU
vessels.
● Refusing officials from the EU to verify compliance with relevant SFPA provisions (such as on
joint inspections).
3. Ensure the transparency of enforcement by:
● Requiring Member States to aggregate information and report annually on enforcement of the MoT derogation, including the number of inspections on EU vessels conducted jointly with a third country, within one year from the entry into force of the implementing act for MoT derogation.
● Requiring Member States to notify the European Commission immediately if there is a risk of a listed port no longer complying with the conditions set out in the implementing act on the MoT derogation
● Requiring the European Commission to make publicly available a compilation of information from the reports on Member States’ efforts to control compliance with the MoT derogation.
 2

 Why stricter control measures and uniform
conditions are necessary
The revision of the EU fisheries control system,1 which entered into force in January 2024, did not change the general rule on how much room EU vessels have to misreport their catches: namely, a margin of tolerance (MoT) of 10 % per species.2 However, the co-legislators considered that complying with this general rule involved “challenges of accurately estimating on board catches”3 for certain fisheries that land unsorted catch. Article 14(4) has therefore been introduced into the revised Fisheries Control Regulation4 (FCR), granting a larger MoT to small pelagic fisheries, industrial fisheries and tropical tuna purse seine fisheries when unsorted catch is being landed.5 The provision further specifies that this wider MoT can only apply if unsorted catch is being landed by these EU vessels in ports that meet conditions concerning landing and weighing that can “ensure accurate catch reporting”6. Based on the submission of Member States, the Commission is to approve ports that meet the conditions. The Commission can subsequently amend this list and “may revoke its approval of a listed port in the event that the conditions are no longer met”7. Both the conditions and the first list of ports should be adopted by 10 July 2024 through implementing acts.8
This guidance note argues that the framework for permitting certain EU vessels the use of the wider MoT must be based on uniform conditions which are exceptionally applied and based on stricter conditions for landing and weighing. This is necessary to (1) ensure consistency with EU law, (2) prevent misreporting, and (3) and avoid damage to the EU’s international standing.
Reason 1: Ensure consistency with EU law
There would not be consistency with EU law if the implementing act specifying the conditions for applying a derogation allowing a wider MoT would not (A) require stricter control measures and (B) uniform conditions.
(A) Stricter control measures
Article 14(4)(a) of the revised FCR expressly stipulates that the new, wider MoT that may be applied “by way of derogation”9 (see appendix below) is conditional. It applies: "in the case of landings in listed ports and” is to be “subject to additional conditions concerning the landing and the weighing of catches in order to ensure accurate catch reporting” (emphasis added). In addition to the revised FCR’s provisions clearly stipulating that this is a derogation that is only applied if certain conditions are met, it is
1 Regulation (EU) 2023/2842 of the European Parliament and of the Council of 22 November 2023 amending Council Regulation (EC) No 1224/2009, and amending Council Regulations (EC) No 1967/2006 and (EC) No 1005/2008 and Regulations (EU) 2016/1139, (EU) 2017/2403 and (EU) 2019/473 of the European Parliament and of the Council as regards fisheries control. PE/38/2023/REV/1. OJ L, 2023/2842, 20.12.2023
2 A margin of tolerance of 10% per species between the estimated quantities recorded at sea in the fishing logbook and the final figures determined at landing. Article 14(3) Regulation (EU) No 2023/2842 (Amendments to Regulation (EC) No 1224/2009).
3 Recital 34, Regulation (EU) No 2023/2842.
4 Article 14(4), Regulation (EU) No 2023/2842 (Amendments to Regulation (EC) No 1224/2009).
5 For exact percentages see, Article 14 (4)(a) and (b), Regulation (EU) No 2023/2842 (Amendments to Regulation (EC) No 1224/2009).
6 Article 14(4), Regulation (EU) No 2023/2842 (Amendments to Regulation (EC) No 1224/2009).
7 Article 14(6), Regulation (EU) No 2023/2842 (Amendments to Regulation (EC) No 1224/2009).
8 Idem.
9Article14(4),Regulation(EU)No2023/2842.WhilethisArticleforesees“bywayofderogationfromparagraph3’ asetofrelaxationsoftheMoT(describedas ‘derogations’ in the Appendix) this note refers to these relaxations collectively as a derogation (in the singular).
    3

 worth recalling three relevant areas of case law of the CJEU that reaffirm the principle that conditional derogations need to be interpreted strictly and applied exceptionally.
Firstly (1), in European Commission v Malta (C-557/15) — a case lost by Malta for failing to demonstrate conditions were in place to exceptionally allow a derogation for trapping of protected bird species in Natura 2000 areas — the Court recalled that “exceptional arrangements” like conditionally applicable derogations, need to be “interpreted strictly”.10 It added that Member State authorities must prove “conditions exist for each derogation” (for it to lawfully apply in their jurisdiction) and:
“ensure that all action affecting the protected species is authorised only on the basis of decisions containing a clear and sufficient statement of reasons which refers to the /.../ conditions and requirements laid down.”11(emphasis added).
Secondly (2), it is settled EU case law that when an undefined term appears in a derogation, it must be interpreted strictly12. The term “accurate catch reporting” of Article 14(4) is not explicitly defined in the revised FCR13. However, in PF, MF v Ireland (C-564/20), a ruling that covered Article 14 of the Regulation (EC) No 1224/2009 and the Member States obligations to ensure “the accuracy of the catch figures”, the CJEU ruled that:
“Member States can properly monitor the uptake of quotas and contribute to the achievement of the objectives of the CFP /.../ only if they can ensure that they have accurate and comprehensive information and data on fishing opportunities”.14 (emphasis added)
Thirdly (3), in Parliament v Commission (C-65/13), a case in which the European Parliament tried (and failed) to argue that the Commission had gone beyond implementing powers that bestowed on it in a legislative act, the CJEU ruled that the Commission is authorised, with reference to the “essential general aims of the legislative act in question” to produce “all measures necessary... for the implementation of the basic legislation” but not those “contrary to it”.15 (emphasis added)
On the first (1) point: It is clear that Article 14(4) of the revised FCR is a derogation that should apply conditionally. Ensuing, as per Commission v Malta, the Commission should strictly interpret its implementing powers in laying down the conditions for the expanded MoT derogation. Since the wording of this article refers to “additional conditions”, it is clear that the conditions to be applied must go beyond the rules for control on landing and weighing already set out (in the FCR, or elsewhere), including those stipulated in Article 60 of the Revised FCR. This is also clear from the considerations of the co-legislators16, as laid out in the recitals. These note that the conditions should “ensure adequate control over such operation[s]”17 (emphasis added). Without stricter conditions for landing and weighing the accuracy of catch reporting cannot be ensured, as also the
10 “In respect of exceptional arrangements, which must be interpreted strictly”, CJEU Judgment of 21 June 2018, European Commission v Malta, C-567/15, ECLI:EU:C:2018:477, paragraph 47.
11 Idem.
12 CJEU Judgment of 11 June 2015, Zh. And O, C‐554/13, EU:C:2015:377, ECLI:EU:C:2018:477, paragraph 42.
13 The term is however invoked repeatedly in the recitals, and Article 14(11) of the Regulation No 2023/2842 (formerly article 14(9)) states that “/t/he accuracy of the data recorded in the fishing logbook shall be the responsibility of the master.”
14 Judgment of 10 February 2022, PF, MF v Ireland, C-564/20, ECLI:EU:C:2022:90, paragraph 41. Cf. Tullio Scovazzi, ‘Legal Analysis on the Margin of Tolerance in the European Union Fisheries Regime’ (2022). https://ejfoundation.org/resources/downloads/Legal-Advice-MoT-Nov-2022-final.pdf (last checked 11 April 2022).
15 CJEU Judgment of 15 October 2014, Parliament v Commission, C-65/13, ECLI:EU:C:2014:2289, paragraph 43-44.
16 The co-legislators noted in recital 34, Regulation (EU) No 2023/2842 that the Commission needs to be conferred implementing powers to “provide further details concerning uniform conditions relating to landing and weighing of fishery products in listed ports”.
17 Recital 34, Regulation (EU) No 2023/2842.
          4

 experience from the Baltic Sea demonstrated [see Box 2]. As vessels will have significantly more incentive to misreport at landing under the MoT derogation applicable for landings of unsorted catch [see APPENDIX], the risk of not ensuring accurate catch reporting increases if the conditions do not go beyond the standard level control on weighing and landing.
On the second (2) and third (3) points: It would be inconsistent with the logic of PF, MF v Ireland (C-564/20) and Parliament v Commission (C-65/13), to allow more room for misreporting via a more flexible MoT. It is clear from C-564/20 in particular that the need to ensure the accuracy of catch reporting is tied to an “essential general aim” (in the sense of C-65/13) of the legislation in question - namely, “monitoring of quota uptake” and “contributing to achieving CFP objective” of ensuring marine biological resources are exploited sustainably.18,19 Putting in place stricter conditions for the application of this MoT derogation to ensure the accuracy of catch reporting at landing is therefore a must. This view is reinforced by the considerations of the co-legislators, which recalled that:
In order to achieve the objectives of the common fisheries policy, the reliability and comprehensive collection of data on catches is of the utmost importance. For that purpose, it is necessary to strengthen the procedures concerning the weighing of fishery products upon landing, without creating disproportionate burdens on operators”20 (emphasis added).
In short, EU case law demonstrates that any derogation needs to be applied exceptionally and interpreted strictly, and that the broader MoT requires additional rules that can ensure the accuracy of catch reporting with adequate control in port. Coupled with the considerations and the provisions of the Regulation No 2023/2842, it can be argued that to require a level of control in listed ports considered to be adequate, such control of EU vessels’ landing and weighing operations in port must be stricter than foreseen by standard rules. Not to do so would be contrary to the EU case law and demands of the co-legislators, as anything but stricter control will not be able to guarantee the accuracy of catch reporting, and by extension, the monitoring of quota uptake.
(B) Uniform conditions
Based on EU primary (EU treaties, case law) and secondary law (the FCR), the conditions under a wider MoT for inspection of unsorted catch at landing must be, at minimum, uniform and applicable in EU and non-EU ports alike.
The Treaty on the Functioning of the EU provides that the Commission lays down “uniform conditions” in an implementing act “where [these] are needed”21. The Court of Justice of the EU (CJEU) has confirmed that such acts must be capable of ensuring that the legislative act in question “is implemented under uniform conditions in all Member States”22.  In a listed port where a MoT derogation would apply, the possibility of inspection and immediate weighing upon landing of unsorted catch needs to be guaranteed with additional safeguards if the accuracy of catch reporting is to be ensured (and risks of a larger MoT are controlled). This includes ensuring that the period between notification and landing is adequate, - long enough - for inspecting a vessel landing immediately (before being stored, transported or placed on the market). The implementing act should accordingly specify these additional safeguards, including those for landings of unsorted catch in third country ports.
One way of doing this is ensuring that for EU vessels landing unsorted catch in EU listed ports, the prior notification period should not as a rule be shorter than 72 hours (as the highest minimum level recommended in RFMOs), while reducing Member States’ discretion to decide when prior notification before this minimum period may happen in third country ports. In such cases, responsible flag Member States should request the European Commission approval for shorter prior notification and demonstrate their ability to ensure physical inspection of vessels landing in a third country port (for example, by having a (joint) inspection team in the port in question (see discussion below box 3, above)).
A second, complementary, approach is to increase the required rate of inspection for EU vessels landing in third country ports. While the PSMA does not set an explicit threshold for the number of inspections, some RFMO, such as the ICCAT and IOTC, with a view to implement the PSMA do.98 For example, IOTC Resolution 16/11 requires each contracting party to “carry out inspections of at least 5% of landings or transshipments in its ports during each reporting year”99 (ICCAT has a very similar rule100). This IOTC rule does not stipulate an inspection101 rate of particular vessels, presenting a potential loophole for missing out on high risk vessels; but this should be required for EU purse seiners landing unsorted catch in listed ports. The European Commission reported in 2024 that ”approximately 6 000 non-EU vessels landed fishery products in EU ports” in 2020-2021 “1 004 were inspected by Member States”102; i.e. nearly 17%, or 1 in 6 foreign vessels were inspected in EU ports. IOTC compliance committee reports suggest that third countries with a high number of port calls by EU purse seiners, like Seychelles have a comparable rate of inspection (of all landings and transshipments) - 13% of all landings/transshipments in 2022 (well above the minimum 5% inspection rate required by Resolution 16/11).103 In order to ensure adequate control of the wider MoT, and consistency with the principles of non-discrimination, it is recommended to set a higher mandatory target rate of enhanced inspections in listed ports of at least 17%, with a risk-based approach that prioritises inspection of ‘serial offenders’ of the MoT derogation. In addition, the conditions for the MoT derogation should account for the possibility that “serial offenders”104 (such as among the French purse seine fleet105) are inspected as a matter of priority.

 Conclusion
Recognising the risks of EU vessels underreporting overfished fish populations, such as yellowfin tuna in the Indian Ocean, it is critical that EU Member States uniformly mitigate these risks and ensure the accuracy of catch reporting and science-based management of the EU’s fisheries. The conditions for when a wider margin of tolerance can be used must therefore require stricter control on landings of unsorted catch (e.g., an unsorted landing of juvenile yellowfin and bigeye tuna), so that accordingly, a limited list of (third country) EU approved ports could be listed.
Doing so also presents an opportunity to lead by example: if the EU’s (tropical tuna purse seine) fleet that is landing catch unsorted is strictly controlled, the accuracy of its catch reporting should improve. This will not only benefit the recovery of already overfished tuna populations, but also enable the EU to effectively call on other countries to better and more credibly promote zero tolerance on unreported fishing, such as part of the IUU Fishing Action Alliance. Conversely, failing to do so could affect the food security of third countries and damage the EU’s negotiating position, such as in RFMOs.
Accordingly, EJF and WWF, members of the EU IUU Fishing Coalition, therefore recommend, the conditions on the MoT derogation should:
1. Require additional safeguards that ensure adequate control with:
● A longer prior notification period, of at least 72h, for EU vessels landing unsorted catch. European Commission’s approval of any shorter notification periods for vessels landing unsorted catch and only after the responsible flag Member State(s) can guarantee it can conduct physical inspection on time.
● Higher mandatory target rates of enhanced inspections in listed ports, of at least 17%, with a risk-based approach that prioritises inspection of ‘serial offenders’ of the MoT derogation;
● The use of accredited independent third parties, where deemed necessary, whose independence should be confirmed by the Member State concerned.
2. Ensure exclusion of any potential ‘ports of convenience’, including those located in third countries that are:
● Failing to comply with the PSMA and (as relevant) RFMO rules on inspections of landing or weighing based on reasonable doubt;
● Yellow or red carded countries under the IUU carding scheme;
● Refusing EU or Member State inspectors to conduct the required level of inspection on EU
vessels;
● Refusing officials from EU to verify compliance with relevant SFPA provisions (such as on
joint inspections).

● Requiring Member States to share in a report annually up-to-date and aggregate information on enforcement of the MoT derogation, including the number of inspections on EU vessels conducted jointly a third country, within one year from the entry into force of the implementing act for MOT derogation;
● Requiring Member States to notify the European Commission immediately if there is risk of a listed port no longer complying with the conditions set out in the implementing act on the MOT derogation;
